bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to [Governor William Gooch], June 29, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to [Governor William Gooch], June 29, 1728, to report that two pipes of wine belonging to the governor have been landed at Corotoman and that he can have them brought to Williamsburg landing if the governor approves.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to [Governor William Gooch], June 29, 1728
div1.p:
This Morning Arrived into this River
Capt. Jas; Tarleton of Liverpool from the Maderas he
hath Landed two pipes of wine here for your Honr:
by order of Mr. Rider the Ship is gone up our river. he
says by his bill of Lading he is not obliged to carry them
any further, Your Lettr. I presume will inform the truth
of this which comes herewith he could not have taken
them in upon any Other Terms, I shall wait your Honrs:
Direction about them. There is a Sloop of Capt. Hopkins
es that must call at my house for Tobbo: in her way down
I Expect her in less then a fortnight she comes by
the Mouth of Queens Creek and no doubt but I can
perswade the Men to bring the wine up to Wms.Burgh
Landing it is so tickleish a Commodity I shall not
Adventure to Send it by this Conveniency unless I have
your Honrs Express orders I am
div1.closer:
Sr.
Your Honrs most Obedt. & mostObliged
& most humble Servt

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.
The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.
See Carter's followup letter to Gooch 1728 July 8 confirming arrangements for the shipment the wine.

[2] This may have been James Tarleton who commanded the The Loyalty in 1731. (Survey Report 9727, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. See Carter's letters to John Pemberton 1730 April 15 and 1731 August 4.)
[3] Mr. Rider was probably a member of the firm of Hayward Miles & Rider of Madeira from whom Carter had ordered wine on 1727 June 29.

[4] Captain James Hopkins commanded the Mary in 1727-1728. He was then working for London merchant Robert Cary. He is mentioned in Carter's diary. (Adm. 68/194, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
